sec.p: In agreement with this, Fried’s research group suggested that frail and non-frail adults may be differentiated much better by assessing the dynamics of their physiological systems’ response to stimuli, instead of the current frailty assessment at only a single time point ( Varadhan et al., 2008). However, the theoretical, practical, and analytical difficulties associated with such a dynamic approach to frailty so far have limited scientific progress in this direction. This is underlined by a systematic review of frailty studies, in which not a single example of such a dynamic approach to frailty was found ( Clegg et al., 2013; Hubbard and Jatoi, 2015). In the following subsection, the concept of subsystem TPs is linked to frailty and resilience and it is shown how this enables a common design for testing resilience in the equilibrium states of, for example, blood pressure, heart rate, and mood.
